newsitem.title: USA: US CREDIT OUTLOOK--CPI, housing starts, production.
newsitem.headline: US CREDIT OUTLOOK--CPI, housing starts, production.

text.p: A big batch of May economic data will attract the market's attention on Tuesday but none of it threatens to sink a buoyant market, analysts said.
The market has climbed steadily since late May, fueled by reports of weak consumer demand and nearly absent inflation.

Monday's action proved no exception to the upward trend. Even without fresh data to drive it higher, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond nonetheless rose 14/32 to 99-4/32, its yield ending at 6.69 percent, the lowest closing yield for the bond since February 25.
The May Consumer Price Index (CPI) and new housing starts figures top Tuesday's calendar of economic reports.
Economists polled by Reuters expect the CPI, due at 0830 EDT/1230 GMT, to be up 0.2 percent in May after a 0.1 percent April rise.
The core CPI, the price measure without its more volatile food and energy items, is also expected to be up 0.2 percent, the economists said, after a 0.3 percent April increase.
Housing starts remained flat, said economists, estimating new starts occurred at a seasonally adjusted, annualized rate of 1.47 million in May versus 1.473 million starts in April.

After the housing and consumer price data releases at 0830 ECT/1230 GMT, the Federal Reserve will report May industrial production and capacity utilization figures at 0915 EDT/1315 GMT. Economists believe industrial production rose just 0.2 percent in May after remaining flat in April partly due to strikes in the automobile sector.

The portion of the nation's mines, factories and utilities employed in that production, known as capacity utilization, is forecast at 83.4 percent, unchanged from the previous month and well below a level that would augur production bottlenecks and attendant inflationary pressures, economists said.
Data on U.S. real earnings in May are due at 1000 EDT/1400 GMT. Earnings fell 0.9 percent in April. A May forecast was not available. The data are not expected to impact the market.
In the midst of the more comprehensive data for May, the market also gets two up-to-date snapshots of consumer demand in June.
BTM/Schroders weekly chain store sales index for the week ended June 14 is due at 0900 EDT/1300 GMT officially, but the index reading is usually rumored in the market before then.
Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc will report the Redbook Index for the same week later on Tuesday at 1455 EDT/1855 GMT.
The BTM Schroders index fell 0.9 percent in the week ended June 7 while the Redbook index rose 2.3 percent. Forecasts for the store sales indices due on Tuesday were not available.
Analysts said if the market is to move higher from here, the gains are more likely to be made at the long end of the maturity range.

"The market can go higher but you really can't rally the front end of the market at this point until you start to make a case for a Fed easing and I don't think most people are ready to do that yet," said Dana Johnson, managing director and research head at First Chicago Capital Markets Inc.
The long end of the maturity range, in contrast, has "a little more value," said Johnson. "You could see the long bond yield move down to 6-5/8 percent and circle around that area."

Johnson said he believes that the middle of the trading range for the bond yield this year is more like seven percent rather than 6-5/8 percent, but that for now, "momentum and the correct belief that the Fed will not change policy in July allows the market to pursue lower yields in the near term."
